content.description:
A big sweeping left-leaning crack that varies from underhung finger to off width and then hand jams and face climbing, the difficult crack is one of the biggest and hardest routes on the main wall.

While it could go on gear it’s mostly climbed on top rope, and the anchors are near the top of the crack, which means that projecting the bottom you want to swing way left of the line. 

The route follows the crack from the bottom where the starting foot is hidden behind a tiny bush, up finger jams and crimps with poor feet into a band of conglomerate with a hand crack that widens into an offwidth that splits around a chock stone. Above the chock stone the line gets easier and trends left with easier hand jams and slabby foot placements. 



The next anchors south from Raspberry Delight on the top, from the bottom it’s just past a small tree growing close to the cliff face. 

Two bolt top anchor at top of the crack. Would also go on a double rack of cams from .3 to 4

A newer bolted dry tool line that can also go on rock, probably about 5.12 or so. No info or beta on wether it’s been climbed without toola



Next obvious line to the right of the corner, look up and see the hanging chains and 2 bolts, and the tool marks are quite obvious. Delicate face climbing with finger cracks and thin ledges in smooth sandstone. 

2 clips and top anchors with rap chains. No top access to the anchor; lead to the anchor or rap off the top to access.

Second dry tool route. Lots of tiny features and horizontal cracks in the rock, unknown if it would go without tools. 



Directly to the right of the dry tool mixed route, the clips, anchor and tool marks are all quite obvious on the face of the sandstone 

3 clips and hanging anchors with chains. No top access without rapping down.

Fun mixed climbing up the face with a combination of slopey conglomerate at the bottom and overhung sandstone at the top, it’s a fun, sometimes pumpy little route that makes a great warmup or beginner project. All the rock is solid and clean, with good hands and tricky feet.

Beware of loose rock and debris when topping out. 



The first climb on the main wall, the line of bolts is fairly obvious when walking south. Down climb from the top, and hike south under the big roof and past the garbage and burnt cars. Round the corner to the left and it’s directly ahead of you on the left side. 

5 bolts and a top anchor with no rings. Bolt #2 is damaged and loose, but a red camalot in the crack directly below it works great.

This route is a clean corner crack that can be climbed as a layback, a crack climb, or with variations on the faces to either side. There is also a variation that goes up the arete on the left using the same start and anchors. Mostly clean sandstone, there can often be water seeping in the back and on the face near the top (hence the name). In wet weather it is often difficult to climb due to water in the crack and the moss that grows quickly. 



Right around the corner from the Face Climb, in the corner it is the obvious line. 

Top anchors with manky chains. Goes on a single set of cams from .75 to 3 easily with strategic placements.

One of the nicest lines on the main wall, an obvious vertical hand crack runs from the ground straight up to the top where it opens into a small ledge system below the anchors. 

Also one of the best and easiest lines to rap down for top access, the wide crack and ledge make down climbing easy. 



The obvious vertical crack in the Center of the left hand portion of the main wall. From the top it is the first set of anchors you see walking along the cliff top trail. 

Top anchors with no chains. A double set of cams from .75 to 2 with a single 3 and a single .5 will be lots to get up with no runout.

The primary bolted area at Bear Mtn. Developed by several people over several years, there’s a little bit of everything and mostly really good rock. Careful inspection the hardware before climbing on anything, as some of the older bolts are occasionally loose or damaged.

As many of these routes have been developed or expanded by various people over several years, there are often unknown or multiple names for some routes. Please msg the person who posted the route if any information is inaccurate or incomplete. The goal is to get as many routes listed as possible so people can find and use them. 

The lookout is a popular party spot and unfortunately this comes with graffiti, vandalism and garbage. Please clean up after yourself and consider packing out other found garbage as well.
